1008860094422028288.text: OK, one final note. This is all about WIRED speed. You want 500 Mbps wifi? Well, tough, you're not getting it. That requires a Macbook Pro at 15' or less clear line of sight, good weather, a freshly sacrificed goat, and squinting while somebody fudges numbers a bit. Sorry. (5/?)

1008859704339107840.text: can run a simple speed test at 750 Mbps+. This means literally *nothing*; many routers that can handle an 850 Mbps speedtest choke and die at WELL under 100 Mbps of actual traffic. (Note: @smallnetbuilder only tests routers that at least have the POTENTIAL to be decent.) (4/?)

1008858291588534273.text: For example, @Netgear's R8000P router gets a WAN-LAN HTTP score of 61.4, meaning it can download stuff at 61.4% the speed a direct or switched gigabit link could. This very roughly equates to 600+ Mbps of traffic.  Note that the same router - and lots of much cheaper ones - (3/?)

1008857731674099712.text: The WAN-LAN score is a percentage. First, Tim downloads a bunch of traffic across a direct gigabit link. Then, he downloads the same traffic across the router, and divides the smaller number by the larger. The result is how close the router gets to true gigabit throughput. (2/?)

1008857408184225793.text: One of the most common questions I get is "what router for 500 Mbps internet" or similar. The tool you're looking for is @smallnetbuilder's router ranker. https://www.smallnetbuilder.com/tools/charts/router/bar/190-http-dn/35 … Specifically, sort by HTTP score WAN-LAN. Now, let's dissect this a little bit. (1/?)

What #wifi really needs is out-of-band control. I dunno why, even 20 yrs ago, anybody thought 1/2-duplex flat collision domains were an acceptable plan.

With OOB mgmt, an AP could regulate the TX airtime each STA got, and STAs could *request* airtime during 100% airtime usage.

959595012228108288.text: The neighbor was using a @NETGEAR PWL1001, and my TL-WPA8630P found *it*, instead of finding its own other half downstairs. 857679099195797504.text: Planning for the future means carefully managing your technical debt, and #GPL is some damn good insurance for that. Embrace it.

857678929322270721.text: If you need to use code that you can't FULLY support internally, GPL is one hell of a lot safer to be dependent on than weak licenses are.

857678469056139264.text: On the other hand a GPL dependency in your code means you have access to future security upgrades, not just to the current code as-is.

857678076519604226.text: You could bundle an MIT-licensed dependency into your code, authors could see your dep, go proprietary. Take upgrades behind a paywall.

857677731059904516.text: People should be more afraid of MIT-style licenses than GPL. Copyleft guarantees you access to *future security upgrades*. MIT doesn't.
